questions.question:
Question 1: The peripheral smear finding of a patient with fever and lymphadenopathy is shown below. 
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The peripheral smear finding shows Downey cells or ballerina skirt cells. These are typically seen 
in infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and cytomegalovirus (CMV). 517 
Sold by @itachibot They are atypical lymphocytes with abundant basophilic cytoplasm containing clear vacuolations 
and prominent nucleoli. They become large as a result of antigen stimulation.

questions.question: Question 2: Bruton tyrosine kinase is involved in which type of B-cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) is associated with B-cell chronic lymphocytic lymphoma/ small 
lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Tumour cells in CLL rely on signals generated by the B-cell receptor for growth and survival. 
These signals are transduced by a cascade of kinases that include BTK. Note: BTK is also defective in patients with congenital X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

questions.question:
Question 3: 506 
Sold by @itachibot A 65-year-old man presents with easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. On examination, 
he is found to have generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Investigations 
show a total WBC count of 1 lakh per microliter, with 80% lymphocytes. Peripheral smear is 
as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings point toward a diagnosis 
of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The peripheral smear shows smudge cells and increased lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm, round 
to slightly irregular nuclei containing clumped chromatin. This large number of monotonous, 
uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes is often described as a "convent-girl" appearance. 518 
Sold by @itachibot Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) / Small lymphocytic lymphoma(SLL) is the most common 
leukemia among adults in the western world. The differentiating point between CLL and SLL is that in CLL the absolute lymphocyte count 
is >5000 per mm³ and in SLL:<5000 per mm³. It is usually asymptomatic at diagnosis but can present with easy fatigability, weight loss, and 
anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are usually seen. • Total blood count: • Total leukocyte count is highly variable; leukopenia is seen when the marrow is involved. • Hypogammaglobulinemia is common and contributes to increased susceptibility to infections. • 10% to 15% of patients develop hemolytic anemia or thrombocytopenia due 
to autoantibodies made by nonneoplastic B cells. • Peripheral smear: • Predominantly shows small lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm • Smudge cells or basket cells or parachute cells - artifacts of the lymphocytes which are disrupted 
during the process of making smears. • Contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often 
described as a convent-girl appearance. • Spherocytes (due to coexisting autoimmune hemolytic anemia) and nucleated RBCs (due to 
premature release of progenitors in face of severe anemia, marrow infiltration by the tumor, or 
both) • Lymph node biopsy: • Diffuse effacement composed of small lymphocytes admixed with variable numbers of larger 
activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose aggregates • Referred to as proliferation centers, which contain mitotically active cells. Proliferation centers 
are pathognomonic for CLL / SLL. 519 
Sold by @itachibot The chromosomal defects: • Deletion of 13q (commonest and has a good prognosis) • Deletion of 11q • Trisomy 12q • Deletion of 17p (poor prognosis).

questions.question:
Question 4: The neoplastic cells in chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic lymphoma originate 
from which of the following?
questions.explanation:
The cell of origin for chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL) is 
either a post-germinal center memory B cell or a naive B cell. The cells of CLL show both unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) and somatic 
hypermutated Ig segments (those of post-germinal center memory B cell). Tumours with unmutated Ig segments (those of naive B-cell origin) pursue a more aggressive 
course.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is not a genetic anomaly seen in patients with chronic lymphocytic 
lymphoma/ small lymphocytic lymphoma? 507 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Deletion of 17p is a genetic anomaly seen in chronic lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL)/ small 
lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL), not trisomy 17p. The genetic anomalies seen in CLL/SLL are: • Trisomy 12q • Deletion of 13q • Deletion of 17p (bad prognosis) • Deletion of 11q (bad prognosis)

questions.question:
Question 6: A 70-year-old man presents with weakness and generalized lymphadenopathy. Lymph node 
biopsy shows difuse effacement with small lymphocytes and proliferation centers. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic 
lymphoma (CLL/SLL). Lymph node biopsy in CLL/SLL shows effacement of normal nodal architecture by sheets 
of predominantly small lymphocytes. They have round to slightly irregular nuclei, condensed 
chromatin, and scant cytoplasm. Admixed are a variable number of larger activated lymphocytes that often gather in loose 
aggregates referred to as proliferation centers. These contain mitotically active cells. When 
present, proliferation centers are pathognomic for CLL/SLL (also known as a pseudofollicular 
pattern). 520 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows a lymph node biopsy of CLL in a low-power view. It shows loss of 
normal architecture and a large, pale-staining area in the center of the node (a proliferation 
center) Lymph node biopsy of 
chronic lymphocytic leukemia Lymph node biopsy of 
chronic lymphocytic leukemia 521 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 58-year-old man with cervical lymphadenopathy is suspected to have chronic lymphocytic 
leukemia. What should be the absolute lymphocyte count/mm3 to diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
The diagnostic requirement for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) is absolute lymphocyte count 
>5000 per cubic millimetre. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL) differ only in the 
degree of peripheral blood lymphocytosis: • CLL - 5000/mm3 • SLL - <5000 cells/mm3 Note: CLL is the most common leukemia of adults in the western world. 522 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: Flow cytometric analysis of four patients is given below. Who among the following is most 
likely suffering from chronic lymphocytic leukemia? 508 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Small lymphocytes of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)/ small lymphocytic leukemia (SLL) are 
CD23 and CD5 positive. Hence, the flow cytometry of patient 1 (CD23 and CD5 positive) correctly 
represents the phenotype of CLL. The tumour cells also express the pan B-cell markers CD19 and CD20 Low-level expression of surface Ig (usually IgM or IgM and IgD) is also typical. Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results: Interpretation of results: œuadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen œuadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens. œuadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens œuadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen

questions.question:
Question 9: A 73-year-old man came with complaints of malaise and low-grade fever. He had generalized 
lymphadenopathy. The histopathological examination of the lymph node is as shown below. 
These cells showed positivity for CD5, CD19, CD20, and CD23. Which of the following does 
not indicate a poor prognosis in this condition? 509 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and histopathological findings are suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia 
(CLL). The presence of NOTCH1 mutation is associated with a poor prognosis in 
chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL). The histopathological image shows small, darker staining lymphocytes with prominent nucleoli 
which are typically seen in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL). 523 
Sold by @itachibot Variables that correlate with a worse outcome include: • The presence of deletions of 11q and 17p • Lack of somatic hypermutation • Expression of ZAP-70 • Presence of NOTCH 1 mutations

questions.question:
Question 10: A middle-aged woman presented with chronic fatigue and generalized lymphadenopathy. 
Investigations revealed overexpression of BCL2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. This condition is associated with 
overexpression of BCL2. It usually presents in middle age as painless generalized lymphadenopathy. The involvement of 
extranodal sites is relatively uncommon. It has an indolent waxing and waning course. In almost 50% of patients, this cancer gets transformed to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. The 
median survival rate is for 7-9 years. The cell of origin for follicular lymphoma is germinal centre B cells. It shows (14;18) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows closely packed follicles. Centrocytes (small cells with the cleaved 
nucleus and scant cytoplasm) and centroblasts (large cells with open nuclear chromatin and 
multiple nucleoli) are seen. Bone marrow is involved in 85% of the cases and shows para-trabecular lymphoid aggregates. 524 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following chromosomal abnormality is likely to be seen in patients with 
follicular lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
Follicular lymphoma shows t(14;18). Its hallmark is a translocation that juxtaposes the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 
locus on chromosome 18. It is seen in up to 90% of follicular lymphomas and leads to 
overexpression of BCL2. BCL2 inhibits apoptosis and promotes the survival of follicular lymphoma cells.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. 
Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this 
condition? 510 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.explanation:
525 
Sold by @itachibot The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less 
inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma. Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive 
course. Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown 
below. 526 
Sold by @itachibot Immunophenotyping: • The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and 
surface Ig. • BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases. Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases. Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows 
a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with longstanding cervical lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with mantle cell 
lymphoma. What is the cell of origin for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Mantle-cell lymphoma arises from the mantle-zone B cells which are naive B cells as they lack 
somatic hypermutation IgH gene. Mantle-cell lymphomas have an (11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 
and overexpression of cyclin D1. It is CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Comparison between mantle-cell lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia/ small lymphocytic

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following statements about mantle cell lymphoma is false?

options.b: Most common presentation is painless lymphadenopathy
options.c: Associated with overexpression of cyclin D1
options.d: Tumor cells are CD5 + and CD23 +

questions.explanation:
The neoplastic cells in mantle cell lymphoma are CD5 positive and CD23 negative. Mantle cell lymphoma usually presents as painless lymphadenopathy. Centroblasts and 
proliferation centers are absent, differentiating it from chronic lymphocytic lymphoma. Immunophenotyping reveals the cells expressing cyclin D1, CD5, CD19, CD20, surface Ig. CD23 is 
negative in these cells.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 53-year-old man was evaluated for painless lymphadenopathy. Biopsy showed a 
homogenous population of small lymphocytes with cleaved nuclear contours. Which 
translocation is seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical picture and pathological findings point toward the diagnosis of mantle cell 
lymphoma. The lymph node biopsy typically shows proliferation consisting of a homogenous population of 
small lymphocytes. The nuclei of these cells have irregular or deeply cleaved contours. Mantle cell lymphoma has(11;14) translocation involving the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the 
cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1. Option A: Follicular lymphoma has t(14:18), not t(18:14). Hence, it is not the answer.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with cervical lymphadenopathy has t(11;14) positive. Which of the following markers 
should be done to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Translocation (11;14) is characteristic of mantle cell lymphoma. The markers to be done to confirm 
the diagnosis, are Sox11 and Cyclin D1. Mantle cell lymphoma is seen in the fifth and sixth decades of life and has a male predominance. 
It is characterised by painless lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly. In some cases, there is multifocal mucosal involvement of the small bowel and colon known 
as lymphomatoid polyposis. It has (11;14) translocation. Lymph node biopsy shows nodal tumour cells may surround reactive germinal centres. 
A homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply cleft 
(cleaved) nuclear contours is typically seen. 528 
Sold by @itachibot Large cells resembling centroblasts and proliferation centres are absent, distinguishing mantle 
cell lymphoma from follicular lymphoma and CLL/SLL, respectively. Immunophenotyping is positive for cyclin D and SOX-11. SOX11 variant that often presents with 
circulating disease with splenomegaly but without significant lymphadenopathy and with a low 
Ki67 index (<10%). Other markers include: • CD 5, CD19 and CD20 +ve • CD 23 -ve • Moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with  or  light chain) The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the immunohistochemistry marker for cyclinD1 negative mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.explanation: SOX11 is the marker used for cyclinD1 negative mantle cell lymphoma. Note: MYD88 is a marker for Waldenstorm macroglobulinemia.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements about marginal zone lymphoma is false?

options.a: They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders
options.b: They spread rapidly to other sites
options.c: They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated
options.d: Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma may occur

questions.explanation:
Marginal zone lymphoma does not spread rapidly to other sites. It remains localised for prolonged 
periods and spread systematically in the later course of the disease. They are B-cell tumours that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. It is the 
most common primary extranodal lymphoma. They arise within tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or infectious 
aetiology: • Salivary gland in Sjögren disease • Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis • Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis They may regress if the inciting agent is eradicated. Antibiotic therapy directed 
against Helicobacter pylori leads to tumour regression. Translocations are associated with MALToma are t(11;18),t(14;18) and t(1;14). These translocations 
then upregulate BCL-10/MALT1, a protein that activates NF-kB and promotes the growth and 
survival of B-cells. They may invade epithelial structures to form lymphoepithelial lesions. Transformation to diffuse 
large B-cell lymphoma may occur.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient with long-standing Hashimoto's thyroiditis was noted to have a swelling in the 
thyroid region. After evaluation, it was diagnosed as a marginal zone lymphoma. What is the 
cell of origin of this lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
529 
Sold by @itachibot Marginal zone lymphomas are considered to be of memory B cell origin. In most cases, they show 
evidence of somatic hypermutation. The category of marginal zone lymphoma encompasses a heterogeneous group of B cell tumours 
that arise within lymph nodes, spleen, or extranodal tissues. They are often referred to as 
MALTomas.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient presents to you with rapidly growing swelling on her right cheek. Past history is 
significant for Sjögren syndrome. You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in her. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Lymphomas arising in the setting of Sjögren syndrome in the salivary gland is marginal-zone 
lymphomas. They often arise in tissues involved by chronic inflammatory disorders of autoimmune or 
infectious aetiology such as: • Salivary gland in Sjögren syndrome • Thyroid gland in Hashimoto thyroiditis • Stomach in Helicobacter gastritis.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following translocations is seen in extra-nodal marginal-zone lymphoma?
questions.explanation:
The translocation seen in marginal-zone lymphoma is t(11;18). Other translocations include 
t(14;18), t(1;14). Marginal-zone lymphoma begins as a polyclonal immune reaction. Signals from the 
antigen-stimulated T helper cells, drive the growth and survival of the clonal B-cells. At this stage, 
it is reversible, as in gastric MALToma after antibiotics against Helicobacter pylori. With time tumour cells may acquire mutations that render their growth and survival 
antigen-independent. Translocations such as t(11;18), t(14;18), or t(1;14) up-regulate the expression 
and function of BCL10 or MALT1 and promote the growth and survival of B cells. These translocations are relatively specific for extranodal marginal-zone lymphomas.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 34-year-old woman came with complaints of chronic lethargy and weakness. Complete 
blood counts revealed pancytopenia. The peripheral smear showed the following picture. 
Which of the following statements is false about this condition? 513 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell neoplasm and not a 
T-cell lymphoma. The peripheral smear shows leukemic cells with fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections 
as shown below. 530 
Sold by @itachibot Patients present with massive splenomegaly and pancytopenia. There is an increased incidence of 
atypical mycobacterial infections, possibly related to frequent unexplained monocytopenia. Activating point mutations in the serine/threonine kinase BRAF is seen in 90% of cases. Peripheral smear shows fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy projections which are best 
recognized under the phase-contrast microscope. The bone marrow aspirate produces a dry tap. A trephine biopsy reveals infiltration by the cancer cells often in the pattern of a honeycomb 
appearance. Leukemic cells have nuclei surrounded by a cytoplasmic halo (fried egg appearance). The neoplastic cells stain positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP). Markers for hairy cell leukemia include: • pan-B-cell markers- CD 19, CD2O • CD11c • CD25 • CD103 • annexin A1

questions.question:
Question 23: A 65-year-old man with a dragging sensation in his abdomen is found to have massive 
splenomegaly. The peripheral blood smear findings are as follows. Which of the following 
markers would you test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and peripheral smear showing fine circumferential cytoplasmic hairy 
projections point towards the diagnosis of hairy cell leukaemia. It's a rare but distinctive neoplasm of the B cells where splenomegaly is often the only abnormal 
finding. Pancytopenia from marrow involvement and sequestration of cells in the enlarged spleen 
is seen in half the cases and infections are seen in one-third of the affected patients. CD103 must be tested among the markers to confirm hairy cell leukaemia. Hairy-cell leukaemias typically express the following markers: 531 
Sold by @itachibot • Pan B-cell markers CD19, CD20, surface Ig (usually IgG) • CD11c • CD25 • CD103 • Annexin A1. Annexin A1 is the most specific and sensitive marker.

questions.question:
Question 24: A histological specimen of the spleen is shown below. Which non-Hodgkin's lymphoma does 
not arise from the area marked as 1?
questions.explanation:
The area marked '1' in the image is the white pulp of the spleen. Hairy-cell leukemia does not arise 
from the white pulp, it involves only the red pulp of the spleen. The other condition involving the 
red pulp is hepato-splenic lymphoma. All the other non-Hodgkin lymphomas (NHLs) involve white pulp. Splenomegaly is the most common and often the only abnormal physical finding in hairy-cell 
leukemia. The spleen in this condition is described as a beefy red spleen. The image given below shows the normal histology of the spleen.

questions.question:
Question 25: A 60-year-old woman presented with generalized itching and mild hypoaesthesia of the skin. 
On examination, maculopapular patches were seen on her back. Biopsy revealed the presence 
of atypical lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei infiltrating the dermis and epidermis. What 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given pathological feature is characteristic of a Pautrier's microabscess. These are seen in 
mycosis fungoides. It is a mature, cutaneous, CD4+ T-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Skin lesions include truncal 
scaling, red-brown patches, plaques, and fungating nodules. Lesions may evolve into a systemic 
lymphoma, with visceral and nodal spread. 532 
Sold by @itachibot Sezary syndrome is a variant of mycosis fungoides. It is the leukemic seeding of blood by 
malignant T cells from the skin (CD4+). It presents with diffuse erythroderma and scaling. Histological hallmark includes: • Sézary-Lutzner cells - cells with cerebriform nuclei (infolded/hyper-convoluted nuclear 
membrane). • Pautrier's microabscesses - tumor cells invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters. • Epidermotropism - invasion of the tumor cells into the epidermis. The image shows sezary cells with cerebriform nuclei in the peripheral smear.

questions.question:
Question 26: A patient presents with generalized exfoliative erythroderma. The peripheral blood smear 
shows the following cell. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a classical Sezary cell with cerebriform nuclei which points towards a 
diagnosis of Sezary syndrome. These are neoplastic T cells. Sezary syndrome and mycosis fungoides are different manifestations of tumors of CD4+ helper T 
cells that are home to the skin. Sezary syndrome is a variant presenting as generalized exfoliative erythroderma. It rarely goes 
into tumefaction and there is associated leukemia of Sezary cells. In Mycosis fungoides, only the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells 
with the characteristic cerebriform appearance. In the later stages of the disease, progression 
occurs to lymph nodes and bone marrow. Tumour cells are not seen in blood. The disease 
progresses through the premycotic phase, plaque phase, and tumour phase.

questions.question:
Question 27: You suspect a lymphoid neoplasm in a patient who is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis. 
On workup, she has splenomegaly and her blood count showed neutropenia and 
lymphocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.a: All forms of this tumour are associated with translocations of the MYC gene
options.b: Endemic forms are latently infected with EBV
options.c: Tumor exhibits a high mitotic index
options.d: Neoplastic cells are usually BCL2 positive

questions.explanation:
533 
Sold by @itachibot A triad of rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia is known as Felty's syndrome. 
Some patients with Felty's syndrome have large granular lymphocytic leukemia as an underlying 
cause. Large granular lymphocytic leukemia is a T-cell (CD3+) and NK-cell (CD56+) variant 
leukemia. They are associated with mutations in the transcription factor, STAT3. Patients usually presents with mild to moderate lymphocytosis and splenomegaly. Neutropenia 
and anemia are also present. Lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly are usually absent. There is an increased incidence of rheumatological disorders associated with this condition. The peripheral smear picture shows large lymphocytes with abundant blue cytoplasm and few 
azurophilic granules. 534 
Sold by @itachibot Non Hodgkin Lymphomas: High Grade
